By Mark Bentley     Nov. 3 (Bloomberg) -- Turkish inflation probably slowed for athird consecutive month in October as a drop in oil costs andconsumer demand outweighed the impact of a decline in the lira.     The inflation rate fell to 11 percent from 11.1 percent inSeptember
column5: an economist at JPMorgan Chase & Co. in Istanbul
column7: inflation will beslower.''     The decline in energy costs
column8: combined with an economicslowdown in Turkey and the European Union
column9: will help lower theinflation rate to between 6.1 percent and 9.1 percent next year
column10: Central Bank Governor Durmus Yilmaz said on Oct. 31.     The central bank will publish its analysis of Octoberinflation data tomorrow. The bank's monetary policy committee nextmeets on Nov. 20.     At 16.75 percent
column11: Turkey's benchmark rate is the second-highest of the 59 countries tracked by Bloomberg after Iceland.                             Weak Lira     The lira slumped in October as investors sold riskieremerging-market assets such as Turkish stocks and bonds. Thecurrency's decline will add 1.2 percentage points to this year'sinflation rate and 1.5 percentage points to 2009 inflation
column12: Yilmazsaid.     The benchmark ISE National 100 Index increased 15 percent to27832.93 last week. The lira strengthened to 1.5451 against thedollar at 5:38 p.m. on Friday from 1.6912 and the yield on thebenchmark government bond tracked by ABN Amro lost 1.26 percentagepoints to 23.14 percent.     The European Commission will publish its annual report onTurkey's progress toward membership of the European Union on Nov.5. The 27-member bloc will criticize the government's failure toclamp down on corruption since Turkey began accession talks threeyears ago

column4: By Garth Theunissen     Nov. 1 (Bloomberg) -- South Africa's rand posted its biggestmonthly loss against the dollar in almost a quarter-century asinvestors sold emerging-market assets amid the world's worstfinancial crisis since the Great Depression.     The rand weakened the most last month since August 1985
column5: headed for its biggest four-week loss inmore than 25 years.     ``The extreme sell-off we've seen in emerging markets isn'tsimply a case of irrational fear but a consequence of the re-pricing of credit and risk taking
column7: anemerging-markets currency strategist in London at BNP Paribas SA
column8: France's largest bank. ``The global credit crunch means there'sless money circulating in the world
column9: which makes investors morediscriminating when it comes to where they put it.''     The rand fell almost 20 percent last month to 9.9200 perdollar by 6 p.m. in Johannesburg yesterday. It weakened versusall 16 major currencies monitored by Bloomberg
column10: falling the mostin October versus the yen. The Australian and New Zealand dollarshad their steepest losses this month versus the U.S. currencysince the mid-1980s.     Emerging-market currencies including Hungary's forint andBrazil's real declined in October as investors cut holdings ofhigher-yielding assets in favor of safer holdings such as U.S.Treasuries. The rand was the second-weakest emerging-marketcurrency monitored by Bloomberg this month after Turkey's lira.                        `Striking Weakness'     ``The weakness in the rand isn't really surprising but theextent of the weakness against its emerging-market peers is quitestriking
column11: '' said Vallee. ``It's come under a lot of sellingpressure.''     BNP Paribas is advising clients to keep ``buying dollars andselling rand
column12: '' for at least the next week
column13: Vallee said.     The currency of Africa's biggest economy slid versus thedollar and yen as interest-rate reductions in Asia
column14: Europe andthe U.S. were unable to prevent a global equities sell-off thaterased more than $10 trillion of market value.     Stocks slipped around the world
column15: with the MSCI World Index  posting its biggest monthly slump on record. South Africa'sFTSE/JSE Africa All Share Index fell for a fifth month
column16: losing 12percent.                         Capital Outflows     Foreigners turned net sellers of almost 67 billion rand ofSouth African stocks and bonds this year
column17: data from its exchangesshow. The nation relies on the inflows to finance its current-account deficit which is expected to reach 7.6 percent of grossdomestic product this year
column18: Finance Minister Trevor Manuel saidOct. 21.     ``South Africa has a gaping current-account hole
column19: which is asevere fundamental imbalance in the economy
column21: an emerging-markets currency strategist at UBS AG in London. ``Itneeds large flows of capital to finance its deficit and that'snot going to happen when the world wants to hold capital ratherthan invest it.''     UBS recommends clients continue ``hedging for downsiderisk'' in the rand against the dollar
column22: euro and yen. ``I thinkthe rand will weaken further
column23: '' said Baweja. The currency maytrade at 10.50 per dollar by year-end ``with the risk of furtherweakness
column24: '' he added.     The rand also weakened this month as commodity prices fell
column25: eroding prospects for earnings from exports. Commodities make upabout half of South Africa's income from abroad
column26: data from theDepartment of Minerals and Energy show.     Gold slid more than 15 percent last month
column27: its biggestplunge since February 1983. Platinum
column28: which rivals gold as thecountry's biggest export
column30: its fourth monthlyloss.     South Africa produces almost 80 percent of the world'splatinum and about 10 percent of its gold
column31: typically causing therand to move in tandem with the metals' prices.                          `Panic Selling'     Government bonds fell in October
column32: with the yield on thebenchmark 13.5 percent security due September 2015 adding 24basis points to 9.09 percent. Yields move inversely to bondprices.     The rand slumped more than 28 percent in August 1985 afterthe government declared a ``debt standstill
column33: '' signaling itsinability to repay foreign lenders. ``Panic selling'' of the randforced the central bank to close its foreign-exchange market
column34: according to the nation's treasury. It later re-negotiated theterms of its debt repayment.     ``It was an absolute disaster for the rand
column36: head of research at Nedbank Treasury inJohannesburg. ``Those were really dark times.''For Related News:Top regional news TOP AFRICA <GO>South African Foreign Exchange TNI FX SAFRI <GO>Top currency stories TOP FX <GO>Top bond stories TOPH <GO>--Editors: Neil MacLucas

column4: By John Fraher     Nov. 3 (Bloomberg) -- Jean-Claude Trichet is extending theEuropean Central Bank's powers just as it gears up for what maybe the fastest round of interest-rate cuts in its 10-yearhistory.     President Trichet has pushed the central bank's reach intothe euro region's neighboring economies as they struggle to copewith the financial crisis
column6: a senior European economist at Merrill Lynch & Co. inLondon. ``Its mandate is being implicitly expanded.''     While Trichet's remit applies just to the 15-nation euroregion
column7: the absence of an institution charged with financialstability across the 27-member European Union created a vacuumthe ECB is trying to fill. In the past three weeks alone
column8: itgave a 5 billion-euro ($6.4 billion) loan to Hungary
column9: set upcurrency swaps with Denmark and Switzerland and increased itslending to euro-region banks to more than $1 trillion.     Hungarian Prime Minister Ferenc Gyurcsany said on Oct. 28he's lobbying EU leaders to allow the ECB to provide liquidityoutside the euro area. ECB Executive Board member Lorenzo BiniSmaghi said on Oct. 31 the bank stands ready to help ``other''eastern European countries that are ``asking for our help.''     The Hungarian
column10: Polish and Czech stock indexes all fell morethan 24 percent last month.                          `Major Danger'     Economists expect more rate cuts from the ECB as it triesto cushion an economy hurtling toward a recession.     The central bank will probably cut its key rate by a halfpoint this week
column12: according to themedian of 50 forecasts in a Bloomberg News survey. It willdeliver another 75 basis points of easing in the following fivemonths.     Consumer and executive confidence in the euro region'seconomic outlook plunged by the most since at least 1985 inOctober
column13: the European Commission said Oct. 30.     ``The ECB is only too well aware that extended
column14: deeprecession is now the major danger facing the euro-zoneeconomies
column16: chief European economist at IHSGlobal Insight in London.     The Bank of England will probably also cut its benchmark by50 basis points
column18: according to a separatesurvey.                          Market Strains     Trichet and other policy makers are still trying to easestrains in financial markets that are crippling the globaleconomy. Europe's corporate debt markets endured their worstmonth on record in October and the gap between the yields on 10-year German and Italian government bonds widened to 1.27 percenton Oct. 31
column19: the most since 1997.     The ECB has responded by ramping up lending to cash-strapped banks
column20: offering unlimited funds. The central bank saidon Oct. 21 that lending to financial institutions jumped to arecord
column21: surging 68 percent from the first week of September.     That may create problems for the ECB as the risk ofpossible collateral losses grows
column23: a formerECB economist and now at Goldman Sachs Group Inc. in Paris.     ``They have challenges for the future in having a balancesheet of unprecedented size
column24: '' said Valla. ``The have to knowhow to deal with such a balance sheet
column25: how much capital theyhave to hold
column26: what it means for risk management. There is awhole set of questions that now have to be answered.''                             Not Alone     The ECB isn't the only European institution trying toguarantee financial stability. The EU said on Oct. 29 it's readyto contribute 6.5 billion euros to an International MonetaryFund-led rescue package for Hungary
column27: and European governmentscoordinated efforts last month to shore up the region's bankingsystem.     Still
column28: some economists and politicians say the ECB'spivotal position at the heart of the financial system should bemore formally recognized.     Hungary's Gyurcsany said on Oct. 28 he wants EU leaders toallow the ECB to accept local government bonds as collateral forforeign-currency swaps
column29: saying ``it is extremely important fromPoland to Hungary to have these repo facilities in place.''     ``My dream is that the ECB gets a financial stabilitymandate
column30: which is not the case so far
column31: '' said Valla. ``The ECBreally has demonstrated it can fulfill such a mandate.''For Related News:Stories on the ECB: NI ECB <GO>On money markets: NI MMK BN <GO>On the credit crunch: NI CRUNCH BN <GO>Search for central bank stories: NSE MONETARY POLICY <GO>Stories on ECB interest rates: STNI ECBACTION <GO>--Editors: Matthew Brockett

column4: By Kim-Mai Cutler and Agnes Lovasz     Nov. 1 (Bloomberg) -- European two-year government notesposted the biggest monthly advance since September 1992 amidspeculation the region's central bank will lower interest ratesnext week to head off a recession in the 15-nation economy.     The gains sent the difference in yield between two- and 10-year bonds to the most in almost four years as shorter-datednotes
column6: a fixed-income strategist inEdinburgh at RIA Capital Markets. ``The market has significantlyshifted its views on the ECB. The rapidly deteriorating economicoutlook points to significant rate cuts and the continued weakperformance of risky assets is giving support to bunds.''     The yield on the two-year German note fell 11 basis pointsthis past week to 2.55 percent by late yesterday in London. Theyield slid 92 basis points since Sept. 30
column7: for its fourthmonthly loss. The 4 percent bond due September 2010 rose 0.16
column11: to102.57.     The yield on the 10-year bund climbed 14 basis points to3.89 percent
column12: paring its decline since Sept. 30 to 12 basispoints. Yields move inversely to bond prices.                        Demand for Safety     The two-year note
column13: which hasn't risen for four consecutivemonths since March 2004
column14: surged as concern the credit-marketmeltdown will push the global economy into a recession sappeddemand for higher-yielding assets. Equities around the worldslumped
column15: pushing the MSCI World Index of stocks to its worstfour-week loss on record.     The spread between two- and 10-year yields widened to 134basis points
column18: a chart of bonds of different maturities.     Ten-year German bunds yielded less than comparable U.S.Treasuries for the first time this week since November 2007.Ten-year U.S. Treasury notes yielded 5 basis points more thanbunds.     The yield spread between bunds and other debt of the samematurity in the region is the widest since 1997 as investorssought the most liquid of government bond markets. The gapbetween bunds and their Italian counterparts widened to 127basis points yesterday. The difference with Spanish 10-year debtwas 69 basis points as the country's economy contracted in thethird quarter for the first time since 1993.                      'Punishing Countries'     ``The market seems to be punishing those countries thathave adopted large-scale rescues for the banking sector
column19: ''Stamenkovic said. ``Italy always seems to be on the firing lineas well because of its poor historical record and fiscaldeficits.''     Gains for bonds may be limited because European governmentdebt sales may reach 750 billion euros ($955 billion) next yearas larger budget deficits and the cost of bank recapitalizationplans boost issuance
column20: according to analysts at UBS AG in London.     ``We expect most of the issuance to occur'' with shorter-dated notes
column22: a fixed-income strategist inLondon at UBS AG
column23: wrote in a client note. ``However the weightof issuance
column24: combined with a lack of buying interest for longer-dated maturities will result in considerably higher realyields'' for longer-dated notes.     Bonds also gained after a government report showedconsumer-price growth in the region slowed this month. Theinflation rate fell to 3.2 percent
column26: the European Union's statistics office in Luxembourgsaid yesterday. That matched the median estimate of 27economists surveyed by Bloomberg.                           Retail Sales     Retail sales in Germany
column28: fellmore than economists expected in September. Sales slipped 2.3percent from August
column29: the Federal Statistics Office saidyesterday. Economists forecast a drop of 1 percent
column30: the medianof 15 estimates in a Bloomberg survey showed.     Inflation in the euro area was last below 3 percent a yearago and has been above the ECB's 2 percent ceiling in everymonth since September 2007.     The ECB participated in a coordinated interest-ratereduction by global central banks on Oct. 8 to prevent thecollapse of the global financial system
column31: reducing its benchmarkrate by half a point to 3.75 percent. The Bank of Japanyesterday lowered its main rate to 0.3 percent to spur growth.     Policy makers meet Nov. 6
column32: when they will probably cut theregion's main refinancing rate a half point to 3.25 percent
column33: according to a Bloomberg survey of 26 economists.     The implied yield on the three-month Euribor futurescontract due in January fell 20 basis points this past week to3.42 percent
column34: suggesting traders are increasing bets borrowingcosts have further to fall.     European bonds outperformed Treasuries this month
column36: compared with 0.1 percent fortheir U.S. counterparts

column4: Review by John Mariani     Nov. 3 (Bloomberg) -- On first sniff I thought the wine wasa little corked. Yet after a few swirls
column5: the problem revealed itself in an explosion of high-alcohol
column7: oaky flavors that seemed to epitomize all that is wrongwith what has been called the globalization of wine.     Here was a wine that was technically unflawed -- clean
column8: smooth and bright. The bottle lingo
column12: it exhibits aromas of ripe redfruits and spices with flavors of red fruit
column14: and anise andnotes of vanilla and chocolate that complement the roundedtannins.''     The repetition of the words ``red fruit'' and ``spice'' inone sentence should tell you something: This is winespeak
column15: hitting all the Pavlovian notes used to describe thousands ofmodern red wines around the world
column17: seeking to cash in on the global taste for big
column18: alcoholic reds.     Andeluna was founded in 2003 by Dallas investor H. Ward Lay
column21: founded Frito-Lay). The younger Lay lives much of the year on his 200
column22: 000-acrecattle ranch in Patagonia.     The Andeluna Pasionado bottle
column23: which sports a sticker fromDecanter magazine awarding a gold medal to the wine
column24: also extolsthe consultant Michel Rolland
column25: a controversial figure in the wineworld who often has advocated pumping up red wines by delayingpicking the grapes until extremely ripe. He also sometimesrecommends using a process called micro-oxygenation
column26: by whichsmall bubbles of oxygen are added to wines to make them rounder
column27: allowing them to age faster in stainless-steel tanks to achievethe slower
column28: natural oxidation that oak barrels provide.     Andeluna's importer
column30: saysmicro-oxygenation is not used for the wine.                            Mature at 5     But the way Andeluna is made is telling: For a five-year-oldwine blended from 35 percent cabernet sauvignon
column32: 20 percent malbec and 10 percent cabernet franc
column34: the tannins very soft. The real problem is that ittastes like a hundred other wines of its kind -- the global tasteyou find when a very new
column35: very well endowed winery lacks thetradition to know just what their vineyards may be capable ofexpressing.     Had I tasted Andeluna Pasionado blind
column36: I would no more guessthat it was from Mendoza than I might think it came fromMendocino County
column41: Sicily.                        Designed for Awards     This is a wine designed to win awards
column42: the kind of cabernetthat California cult wine faddists say will ``blow your doorsoff.'' It tastes more of the lab than of the individual vineyard
column43: like prune juice more than good wine
column45: solacking in a fine edge of acid
column46: that my wife and I left half thebottle undrunk while having a simple dinner of grilled pork chopsand white beans.     The fact that the label noted a minimum alcohol volume of14.7 percent also made this something of an ordeal to finish.This is not outrageously high for a cabernet blend
column47: though it issymptomatic of the levels achieved where the wine tastes ``hot''and the nose is full of alcohol.     Andeluna Pasionado is not a poorly made wine -- in fact
column48: it's a very carefully made wine -- but it is not the kind of winethat expresses the best coming out of Argentina's Mendoza Valley
column49: where malbec has shown the most distinction as a varietal. It istoo big
column50: too rich and too alcoholic. It lacks both dimension andthe character of terroir.     There is a lot wrong with a world of wine where attempts aremade to have every varietal taste more or less the same and wherehugeness and over-ripeness are seen as a virtue as much as theyare a marketing strategy.     (John Mariani writes on wine for Bloomberg News. Theopinions expressed are his own.)For Related News:More wine reviews: NI WINEREV <GO>Wine auction stories: TNI WINE AUCTION <GO>Top stories about arts and culture: MUSE <GO>--Editors: Stephen West

column29: and 38 percentpredicted it would shrink. Just 2 percent forecast it wouldexpand 2 percent or more.     The U.S. economy
column31: grew 2.9 percent ayear on average over the last decade.     The poll was taken between Oct. 10 and Oct. 23
column32: and includedresponses from 102 members of the business economists group.For Related News:For stories on the U.S. economy: TNI USECO ECO BN <GO>.Stories on inflation: TNI US INF <GO>.--Editors: Brendan Murray

column4: By Bob Willis     Nov. 3 (Bloomberg) -- Manufacturing in the U.S. probablycontracted in October at the fastest pace since the 2001recession as the credit crisis deepened and companies slashedorders
column6: a senior economist at BMO Capital Markets in Toronto
column7: said before the report. ``It's the stuff recessions are made of.The longer we go without credit
column8: the greater is the risk therecession will be more severe.''     The Tempe
column9: Arizona-based ISM's factory report is due at 10a.m. New York time. Forecasts from the 63 economists surveyedrange from 38 to 48.5.     A report from the Commerce Department at the same time mayshow spending on construction projects fell 0.8 percent inSeptember
column10: according to economists surveyed. Commercial building
column11: after holding its own as housing collapsed
column12: has begun weakeningand will contribute to the drop
column14: Election     As financial markets imploded in the last two months and theBush administration led a massive bid to rescue banks
column15: Democraticcandidate Barack Obama took the lead in polls over Republicanrival John McCain as voters perceived the Illinois senator wouldbe better able to address economic concerns.     The seizing up of credit markets since mid-September hasworsened the outlook. Companies are cutting back on investmentsand hiring as consumer spending in the third quarter plunged by3.1 percent
column16: the biggest decline in 28 years.     GMAC LLC
column17: the lender partly owned by General Motors Corp.
column18: is telling some GM dealers it will no longer provide financing tobuy vehicles because of its own reduced funding
column19: according toletters sent to the retailers.     ``Turbulence in the markets reduced our access to funds andincreased the cost of funds where available
column20: '' GMAC ChiefExecutive Officer Alvaro de Molina said in a letter sent Oct. 21to the California New Car Dealers Association. ``In response
column21: weadjusted our credit policy to reflect the reduced level offunding availability.''                      Economy Contracts     The economy shrank at a 0.3 percent pace in the thirdquarter
column22: with spending on equipment and software declining at a5.5 percent rate
column23: the biggest drop since the first quarter of2002. Economists surveyed by Bloomberg forecast the economy willshrink at a 0.8 percent rate in the fourth quarter.     In a bid to keep the downturn from becoming the worstrecession in the postwar era
column24: the Federal Reserve last week cutits key rate a half point to 1 percent
column25: matching a 50-year low.     ``Business equipment spending and industrial production haveweakened in recent months
column26: and slowing economic activity in manyforeign economies is damping the prospects for U.S. exports
column27: ''the Fed said. ``Downside risks to growth remain.''For Related News:For U.S. economy stories: TNI US ECO <GO> OR NI USECO <GO>For U.S. manufacturing stories: TNI US MAC <GO>For stories on manufacturing and trade: TNI TRD MAC <GO>*T                          Bloomberg News================================================================                               ISM      ISM Construct                              Manu   Prices Spending                             Index    Index     MOM%================================================================Date of Release              11/03    11/03    11/03Observation Period            Oct. column4: By Jeff Wilson     Nov. 3 (Bloomberg) -- Corn and soybeans may rise for asecond week on speculation that government interest-rate cutsand banking bailouts around the world will boost food and feeddemand in 2009.     Twenty of 35 traders
column5: William Bi in Beijing and Sungwoo Park in Seoul.Editors: Ted Bunker

column4: By Tiffany Kary and Christopher Scinta     Nov. 3 (Bloomberg) -- In the last quarter century
column5: using holiday salescash to jump-start reorganizations or finance liquidations.     This bankruptcy season is different. Retailers with reducedrevenue or bloated debt are closing down early because of aconsumer spending slump linked to the credit crunch
column6: dwindlinginventory values and restrictive changes in the bankruptcy law
column8: a lawyer at Chicago-based Kirkland & Ellis.More liquidations are coming
column9: he said.     ``There's going to be tension between allowing retailers toget through the holiday season versus liquidating in Decemberwhere a lender may have the best chances of getting repaid
column11: who specializes in bankruptcy law.     Already Value City Department Stores LLC
column13: jumped the January gun and filed for bankruptcyOct. 27
column14: saying it would conduct close-out sales. Three companiesalready in bankruptcy -- Linens 'n Things Inc.
column21: employed by Kmart Corp. andjewelry retailer Zale Corp. in years past
column22: was designed to buildup a war chest to attract investors as part of a reorganizationor to pay off lenders that might then provide bankruptcyfinancing
column23: lawyers said. Holiday sales sometimes helped avoidbankruptcy if companies got lucky with a buying spike.     Tight credit markets have dried up bankruptcy financing --so-called debtor-in-possession or DIP loans
column24: Henes said. WithoutDIP loans to finance a reorganization
column25: companies will be forcedto go out of business. The incentive to soften up lenders withpayoffs aimed at getting DIP loans doesn't apply now
column27: a bankruptcy lawyer at New York-based Proskauer Rose.                        Retail Bankruptcies     Among distressed companies
column28: electronics retailer CircuitCity Stores Inc. has hired a turnaround firm
column29: FTI Consulting Inc.to try and reverse six straight quarters of declining sales.Department store Boscov's Inc.
column31: is hopingto find a buyer to avoid liquidation. Borders Group Inc.
column32: searching for a buyer to rescue it from $11 million in second-quarter losses
column33: a lack of financing and tough competition
column34: hasfailed so far to find one.     Retailers with distressed bonds tracked by Bloomberg includeFinlay Fine Jewelry Corp.
column42: and Rite Aid Corp.                      The January Phenomenon     From 1980 to 2008
column43: of the 105 large public retailers thatfiled for bankruptcy with assets of more then $100 million
column44: onlyseven did so in December
column45: giving up the full benefit a holidaycash infusion
column46: according to statistics compiled by Lynn LoPucki
column47: a law professor who teaches at Harvard University and theUniversity of California.     That was less than half the 18 that did so in January -- themost popular filing month for large retailers -- and slightlyless than the 10 that filed in February after January clearancesales
column48: he said.     ``Seventy to 80 percent of bankruptcy filings in the retailsector traditionally take place at the end of high sellingseasons
column50: a managing member at Tiger CapitalGroup LLC
column51: a retail liquidation contractor since 1972.     No longer
column54: and the companies along with the creditors arefinding that if they wait
column55: the value of the inventory is going tobe substantially lower.''                        Inventory Pressure     Companies specializing in electronics
column58: and other popular gift items would benefit more from a pre-Christmas liquidation
column59: while inventory values for items likefurniture and other holiday items are actually higher in January
column61: which has helped Linens `n Things and ValueCity liquidate
column62: estimates that companies that liquidate inNovember or December may get 10 percent to 20 percent more thanif they wait until January when consumers' gift-giving impulsesare over.     ``Confidence has deteriorated so badly that merchants andbankers don't even believe in Santa Claus any more
column64: senior managing director at National CityCapital Markets
column65: said that if a retailer is severely distressedwith debt payments
column66: a cash shortage or sagging sales
column67: liquidatingbefore Christmas is ``a better alternative'' than waiting.     Gordon Brothers Group
column69: is ``actively talking to potential clients who are looking atliquidations now
column70: '' said Chief Investment Officer WilliamWeinstein. He predicts that companies that had limited purchasingpower last spring -- when most retailers stock up for holidaysales -- will go into early liquidation. For retailers that werehealthy then
column71: most will see out the Christmas season
column72: he said.                            Value City     Value City
column74: said in its bankruptcy filing thatwithout enough money to keep its shelves well-stocked with enoughinventory
column75: it couldn't keep operations at a profitable level orkeep borrowing money under its credit agreement with lenders.     Kirkland's Henes said changes to the U.S. bankruptcy law in2005 are also encouraging retailers to liquidate rather thanreorganize. One amendment gives trade creditors that suppliedgoods to a company within 20 days prior to its bankruptcy a so-called administrative claim. Such claims need to be repaid beforemost others
column76: so lenders thinking about DIP financing need tofactor in such payments now.    Another amendment requires companies to assume or rejectleases within 270 days of their bankruptcy filing. That's shorterthan previously
column77: when judges granted routine extensions of lease-rejection deadlines. The new deadline is a particulardisadvantage to retailers considering liquidation of some storesbecause it can take more than 270 days to determine whichlocations should survive
column78: Henes said.For Related News:For a menu of top consumer news

column4: By Elizabeth Amon     Nov. 3 (Bloomberg) -- A New York judge rejected HexionSpecialty Chemicals Inc.'s request to force two banks to extendtheir financing commitment for its $6.5 billion takeover ofHuntsman Corp.     State Supreme Court Justice Eileen Bransten in Manhattandisagreed with Hexion's claim that it would suffer ``irreparableharm'' if Credit Suisse Group AG and Deutsche Bank AG didn'tleave the funding agreement in place beyond the Nov. 1 deadline.     Hexion
column5: has led the group to considera new transaction at a price less than the original $28 a share.     Hexion believes it may be able to force the banks to fundthe Huntsman deal even after the expiration date
column8: a Hexion lawyer. Hexion sued the CreditSuisse and Deutsche Bank units on Oct. 29
column9: asking a judge toorder them to ``fulfill their obligations to finance themerger.''     Hexion agreed last year to buy The Woodlands
column11: the world's biggest maker of epoxy adhesives. Thetransaction was delayed by legal disputes over financing and wasscheduled to be completed Oct. 28.     ``All of the time Hexion could have moved
column12: could have donethings well in advance of the Nov. 1
column15: '' Branstensaid Oct. 31 following a hearing. ``If Hexion had done so
column16: itwould have eliminated the urgency to do something today.''     The banks notified Hexion of their decision on Oct. 27
column18: Ohio-based company said in a statement. Credit Suisse
column20: and Deutsche Bank of Frankfurt rejected asolvency opinion by American Appraisal Associates Inc. and acertificate signed by Huntsman's chief financial officer.     Apollo
column21: the New York-based private-equity firm run by LeonBlack and Joshua Harris
column22: initially made a similar argument aboutthe combined company's finances. Huntsman sued Hexion in June inDelaware Chancery Court to meet the terms of their takeoveragreement.     Chancery Judge Stephen Lamb on Sept. 29 sided with Huntsman
column23: ruling that a slump in the chemical markets didn't give Hexiongrounds to terminate the purchase and ordered the company tohonor the agreement.     On Oct. 21
column24: Hexion lost a bid to extend the period duringwhich the buyout must take place. Hexion on Oct. 27 filed anappeal of Lamb's September ruling in Delaware Supreme Court.     ``We will continue to pursue our claims for damages in bothDelaware and Texas
column26: a Huntsman spokesman.``Whatever the status of Hexion's arguments versus the banks
column27: webelieve Huntsman has been harmed by both Hexion's and the banks'actions.''    Kasowitz said Hexion won't seek an appeal of the decision andwill return to court today to ask Bransten to order the banks tofund the merger. Kasowitz argued that Hexion believes the banksare obligated to provide the financing even after the commitmentletter expires.     Richard Clary
column29: told Bransten thatthe banks don't accept that argument.     The case is Hexion Specialty Chemicals Inc. v. CreditSuisse
column31: New York State Supreme Court (Manhattan).Kerviel's SocGen Bosses Told Him to Hide Bets
column32: Mediapart Says     Jerome Kerviel said his three immediate superiors at SocieteGenerale SA knew about his bets before the bank claimed itdiscovered the positions that led to its record trading loss
column34: citing a transcript of a meeting between theauditors
column36: defense and judges.     The three were complicit in his actions because ``they letme act while they were perfectly aware of the positions beingtaken
column37: '' Kerviel said to judges investigating the 4.9-billion-euro ($6.2 billion) loss
column38: according to the transcript publishedby the on-line news service.     ``There were instructions to disguise the surplus end-of-year results
column40: when asked why he covered up a1.4 billion-euro profit at the end of 2007
column41: according toMediapart.     Kerviel said he didn't tell the bank his bosses knew whathe'd been doing when first asked to explain the unauthorizedtrades in mid-January because he was ``stressed
column43: citing the transcript.     Lawyers for the bank and Kerviel declined to comment on thereport when contacted by Bloomberg News.For more lawsuits news from last week

column46: click here.                       Verdicts/SettlementsNational Century's Lance Poulsen Convicted of Fraud
column48: former chief executive officer of NationalCentury Financial Enterprises Inc.
column49: was convicted of defraudinginvestors of $2.9 billion before his health-care financingcompany collapsed in 2002.     A federal jury in Columbus
column51: found Oct. 31 that Poulsenis guilty of fraud
column54: cheated investors who bought National Century bonds to back thepurchase of unpaid insurance bills from medical providers thatneeded cash
column55: prosecutors said. The company advanced $2.2 billionto six companies in which Poulsen owned a stake
column56: they said.     ``This is one of the largest frauds the FBI has everinvestigated
column57: '' Justice Department trial attorney Leo Wise toldjurors during the trial. ``Investors were told their money wouldbe used to buy accounts receivable. They got a worthless IOU inmany cases from a health-care provider teetering on the edge ofbankruptcy.''     Poulsen
column60: facesfrom 30 years to life in prison. He already is serving 10 yearsafter his conviction in March for trying to bribe the mainwitness against him.     The case is U.S. v. Poulsen
column63: Southern District of Ohio (Columbus).ICO Wins $236 Million Punitive Damages Verdict Against Boeing     ICO Global Communications Holdings Ltd. won $236 million inpunitive damages against Boeing Co. and one of its units over afailed agreement to build a satellite telecommunications network.     Jurors in Los Angeles Superior Court awarded ICO $59 millionagainst Boeing Satellite Systems and $177 million against theparent company on Oct. 31. The punitive damages come on top of$370.6 million in compensatory damages the jury awarded Reston
column64: Virginia-based ICO on Oct. 21.     The jurors last week agreed with ICO's arguments that Boeingunfairly demanded additional money to finish and launch thesatellites
column65: which ICO ordered to create mobile-phone connectionsto remote locations worldwide. Boeing said it would appeal theverdict
column66: which was the fourth-largest in the U.S. this year
column67: according to Bloomberg data.     The case is Boeing Satellite Systems International Inc. v.ICO Global Communications (Operations) Ltd.
column69: LosAngeles County Superior Court.Schering to Pay $31 Million to Resolve Missouri Medicaid Claims     Schering-Plough Corp. agreed to pay $31 million to the stateof Missouri to resolve claims it overcharged the state's Medicaidprogram for some medicines.     The settlement resolves allegations that Schering's Warrickunit inflated prices for medicines in a way that way that costMissouri taxpayers millions of dollars
column71: a spokesmanfor State Attorney General Jay Nixon
column72: said in an e-mailedstatement.     On Oct. 30
column73: a jury in St. Louis ruled that Kenilworth
column74: NewJersey-based Schering must pay $7.3 million in compensatorydamages for the overcharging. The panel was to meet Oct. 31 todetermine whether to award punitive damages.     Schering spokesman Lee Davies did not return a telephonecall seeking comment.DuPont
column75: Rhodia Win Dismissal of Invista Trade Lawsuit     DuPont Co. and Rhodia SA won dismissal of a lawsuit by KochIndustries Inc.'s Invista unit
column77: accusing the chemical companies of conspiring to steal a tradesecret.     DuPont sold Invista to Wichita
column78: Kansas-based Koch in 2004for $4.2 billion. The transaction included the sale of so-calledGen 1 technology to produce adiponitrile
column80: a chemical usedto make some types of nylon
column81: according to a complaint filed byInvista in August in federal court in Manhattan.     ``The court lacks subject matter jurisdiction and dismissesInvista's complaint
column82: '' U.S. District Judge Barbara Jones wrote ina 12-page opinion Oct. 31. Jones said in her opinion thatInvista's claims were made under state law and gave Invistaapproval to refile those claims.     Invista claimed DuPont
column84: agreed to operate an ADN manufacturing plant in Asia forRhodia that would use Gen 1 technology. Rhodia
column86: had learned about the ADN process through a confidential jointventure with Invista in France
column87: Invista claimed. Rhodia joinedforces with DuPont to build an ADN plant in Asia and ``to competeunfairly
column88: '' according to the complaint.     Daniel Turner
column91: didn't have an immediate comment. An Invistarepresentative didn't return a call seeking comment.     Invista said the Gen 1 process
column93: produces high-quality ADN and leads to hundreds ofmillions of dollars in annual revenue. In its French jointventure with Rhodia
column94: Invista said it insisted that itsproprietary technology remain protected.     Rhodia has been teaming up with DuPont to use Gen 1technology to manufacture ADN in Asia
column95: where demand is expectedto ``dramatically increase in the next decade
column97: alleging that their ``conspiracy'' is a theft of acritical trade secret.     The case is Invista v. DuPont
column100: Southern District of New York (Manhattan).Sidel Investors Should Be Awarded Higher Damages
column101: Court Says     Investors in Sidel SA
column102: whose machines once made more thanhalf of the world's plastic drink bottles
column103: won a court bid toincrease an earlier verdict awarding them 10 euros ($13) a sharein connection with the sale of the company.     The Paris Court of Appeals said at a hearing Oct. 31 that itwould add extra damages to the initial 10 euro per share award.The amount of extra damages may be determined later at thehearing.     About 700 shareholders appealed the 2006 ruling validating a2 million-euro settlement that Sidel paid four years earlier toDeminor International SCRL
column104: a consultant to holders of minoritystakes
column105: to resolve the claims of about 1
column106: 000 investors.     The investors told the appeals court that they only acceptedthe offer because they'd been kept in the dark about thecompany's financial status. A report by the French marketregulator found that the company and former directors publishedfalse or misleading information and overstated profits from 1998through 2000.     The investors said they would never have bought shares hadthey known the truth of Sidel's financial situation. Nor wouldthey have accepted
column108: a 50-europer share buyout offer by Switzerland's Tetra Laval InternationalSA in 2001. The European Commission vetoed the deal asanticompetitive. That decision was overturned on appeal and thesale was completed in January 2003.For more verdict and settlement news from last week

column110: click here.                      Litigation DepartmentsFred Baron
column113: the lawyer who won billions of dollars forclients in asbestos cases and served as finance chairman of JohnEdwards's presidential campaign
column114: died of blood cancer Oct. 30 athis home in Dallas. He was 61.     Baron
column115: a founder of the Baron & Budd law firm
column116: said he hadworked as a youth sweeping mounds of asbestos from a factoryfloor. He later built his legal career by suing makers and usersof the material
column117: including W.R. Grace & Co. and Halliburton Co.
column118: over claims that exposure caused lung disease and mesothelioma
column119: afatal cancer. Baron & Budd also represented clients claiminginjuries from drugs and toxic chemicals.     ``Fred Baron left his fingerprint on the law
column122: the Houston lawyer whorepresents Baron's family and worked with him on a $4.5 billionasbestos settlement
column123: said Oct. 31 in a telephone interview.``This world is a better place because of Fred Baron.''     Baron received a Biogen Idec Inc. drug to treat his cancerearlier in the month after pleas by former President BillClinton
column124: cycling champion Lance Armstrong and Baron's wife
column126: who also is an attorney at Dallas-based Baron & Budd. Baronwas days from death
column129: wrote in a letter to thecompany sent Oct. 15.     The U.S. Food and Drug Administration authorized anoncologist at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester
column133: under a rule for compassionate use. Thedrug is approved to treat multiple sclerosis and Crohn's diseaseand is in the early stages of testing for multiple myeloma
column134: theblood disease that killed Baron.Broadcom Appoints Technology Lawyer Chong as General Counsel     Broadcom Corp.
column135: the chipmaker that has fought rival QualcommInc. in courts since 2005
column136: named technology and insurance lawyerArthur Chong general counsel.     Chong
column138: spent more than 20 years at McKesson Corp.
column139: a SanFrancisco-based information-technology and health-care servicescompany
column140: before joining Seattle-based insurance company SafecoCorp. as chief legal officer in 2005. He will start immediately
column141: Broadcom said Oct. 31 in a statement.     Broadcom
column142: which makes chips for flat-panel televisions andApple Inc.'s iPhone
column143: is entangled in royalty and patent suitsover its technology. Those include multiple disputes withQualcomm that followed Broadcom's expansion into the mobile-phonesemiconductor market four years ago.     Chong replaces Alvin Segel
column144: a California lawyer who wasnamed acting general counsel in May after his predecessor DavidDull was sued by regulators over the dating of stock optionsalong with co-founder Henry Samueli.For more litigation department news from last week
column145: click here.                          On the DocketNigeria Adjourns $44 Billion Tobacco Suit to January
column146: AFP Says     A Nigerian court adjourned a $44 billion lawsuit againstBritish American Tobacco Plc and other cigarette makers untilJan. 19
column148: citing legaldocuments.     Judge Adamu Bello gave the government permission to servePhilip Morris International Inc. with a summons via diplomaticchannels after four failed attempts to notify the company
column149: thenews service said. Nigeria is demanding $44 billion in damagesfor the costs of treating smoking-related diseases
column151: the maker of Pall Mall and Lucky Strike cigarettes
column152: said in an e-mailed statement it will ``vigorously'' defenditself
column154: a spokesmanfor Philip Morris International Inc.
column155: said the company has noactivities in Nigeria
column156: nor has it received anything linked tocivil claims in the country through diplomatic channels.                          Court FilingsLehman Bankruptcy Docket Is Most-Read Legal Document     Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc.'s bankruptcy docket was themost-read legal document on the Bloomberg last week.     Lehman
column158: filed thelargest bankruptcy in history on Sept. 15 with $613 billion inliabilities.     The bankruptcy docket of Washington Mutual was the secondmost-read legal document last week
column159: followed by the docket for aHexion Specialty Chemicals suit.     The case is In re Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc.

column4: By Susanna Ray     Nov. 1 (Bloomberg) -- Boeing Co. machinists will castballots today on whether to end the third-longest walkout in theplanemaker's history as they pick up their $150 weekly unionstrike stipends in Washington
column5: which union leaders unanimously endorsed this week.     The 57-day strike has idled Boeing's Seattle-areamanufacturing hub
column6: cutting profit by $10.3 million and revenue by$100 million each day and further delaying the new 787Dreamliner. Even if employees accept the new contract and startgoing back to work tomorrow night as planned
column7: the company mayneed until December to get assembly lines back up to speed
column9: an analyst at Barclays Capital in New York.     ``Boeing doesn't want to budge in anything that would affectits competitive position in a downturn
column10: so this is probably thebest deal the machinists are going to get given the economy andthe way the market is headed
column12: ananalyst with aviation consulting firm Teal Group in Fairfax
column14: who has been a Boeing watcher for more than 20 years.``Still
column15: there is a lot of anger toward management'' that couldprompt some workers to reject the new offer
column17: the contract needs support from 50 percent of thevoters
column18: plus one. The voting takes place today from 8 a.m. to 6p.m. local time and the results will be announced when all theballots have been counted
column19: the union said. The voting in thePuget Sound area is taking place at the union hall
column20: fairgroundand community college were workers have been picking up weeklystrike-pay checks in person on Saturdays since Sept. 27.                         Record Profits     The machinists
column21: who build planes and parts and maintain thefactories
column22: walked out Sept. 6 after an 80 percent ``no'' voteagainst Chicago-based Boeing's first offer. The union maintainsthat Boeing's record profits since the last contract andunprecedented orders have made it an ``island of success'' in theslumping economy and that its members deserve a greater share ofthe work and the earnings.     Boeing had a record order backlog for 3
column23: 725 planes worth$276 billion at the end of September
column24: boosted by airlines eagerto save on fuel by using newer models.      The company has said it needs to make sure any contractimprovements still would be affordable if there's a slowdown andthat it needs to continue its outsourcing policy to remaincompetitive as new aviation companies are founded and its onlylarger rival
column27: builds plants inChina.--Editors: Kevin Miller

column4: By Amy Thomson     Nov. 3 (Bloomberg) -- Verizon Communications Inc.
column5: down from a low of $95 previously
column6: spokesman Bill Kula said. Verizon is also introducing pared-downbundles of voice and Internet or TV at lower prices.     The cuts may make Verizon more attractive than cablecompetitors
column7: such as Time Warner Cable Inc.
column8: which offers itstriple-play packages for as low as $89.85 a month for the firstyear of a three-year contract. Customers have been leaving phonecompanies to take advantage of discounts from cable providers.     ``More than anything
column9: it just reflects the intensecompetitive nature of the industry right now and the need to getmore aggressive on price to win share
column10: '' Robert W. Baird analystWill Power said in an interview. ``Price still matters intelecom.'' Power rates Verizon shares ``neutral.''     The new prices
column11: which affect packages with copper phonelines
column12: high-speed Internet and DirecTV Group Inc.'s digital TVservice
column13: will be maintained for the first year of a customer'sservice
column14: Verizon's Kula said. It's unclear if prices will riseif a subscriber renews the contract
column15: he said.     Verizon shares fell 83 cents
column17: to $29.67 inNew York Stock Exchange composite trading on Oct. 31. The stockhas declined 32 percent this year.                        Premium Channels     FiOS
column18: the company's fiber-optic Internet and TV service
column19: isoffering 90 days of free HBO
column20: Cinemax and other premium channelsto encourage cash-strapped customers to pay for extraentertainment at home
column21: spokeswoman Bobbi Henson said.     ``With the current economy
column23: ''Henson said. ``Home entertainment is the way people are going toget entertainment.''     Verizon lost 1.19 million home-phone customers in the thirdquarter. AT&T Inc.
column24: the largest U.S. phone company bysubscribers

column4: By William Freebairn and James Attwood     Nov. 3 (Bloomberg) -- The following companies may haveunusual price changes today in Latin America trading. Stocksymbols are in parentheses
column5: the brokeragewrote. TGS rose 9.3 percent to 1.29 peso.                           Brazil     Banco do Brasil SA (BBAS3 BS): The country's biggest bankagreed to buy 5.25 billion reais ($2.4 billion) of bank loansfrom other financial institutions
column6: O Estado de S. Paulo said Oct.31. The bank acquired loans from 14 financial firms in October
column8: citing an e-mailed statement sent by bankvice president Aldo Luiz Mendes. Banco do Brasil rose 0.8 percentto 14.77 reais.     Kroton Educacional SA (KROT11 BS): The Brazilianadministrator of private schools and colleges that sold sharesin July boosted its share repurchase program by 53 percent.Kroton said it plans to buy back as many as 1.23 million shareunits
column9: each representing 1 voting share and 6 non-voting shares.Kroton was unchanged at 8 reais.                           Chile     Cencosud SA (CENCOSUD CC): Chile's biggest retailer had its``buy'' rating reiterated at Banco Santander SA after reportingthird-quarter operating profit that matched estimates. Cencosudprobably will be able to lower expenses and remain financially``healthy
column10: '' analysts including Antonio Cruz wrote in an Oct. 31note to clients. Cencosud rose 1 percent to 983.43 pesos.     Concha y Toro SA (CONCHA CC): Chile's biggest wine exporterreported third-quarter earnings before interest
column12: depreciation and amortization that missed Banco Santander'sestimates. The results suggest wine consumption is being hitharder than previously thought by the credit crisis
column13: Paula Vicunaand other analysts wrote in an Oct. 31 note to clients. Concha yToro rose 0.3 percent to 930 pesos.                          Mexico     Cia. Minera Autlan SAB (AUTLANB MM): The largest manganeseproducer in North America said it plans to temporarily close aferroalloy plant that accounts for 14 percent of production. Theplant
column14: which was scheduled to be closed Nov. 1
column15: will re-open oncedemand increases. Autlan rose 9.6 percent to 35.50 pesos.--With reporting by Heloiza Canassa in Sao Paulo and ThomasBlack in Monterrey. Editors: Sylvia Wier
